snippet: Tashfeen Malik passed three background checks by American immigration officials but none uncovered what she had said online about her views on violent jihad.
abstract: Investigators say Tashfeen Malik, who carried out massacre in San Bernardino, Calif, with her husband Syed Rizwan Farook, passed three immigration background checks despite sharing views in support of violent jihad on social media; revelation points to both shortcomings of immigration system and difficulty of screening online activity of tens of millions of people admitted to United States each year.

byline.original: By MATT APUZZO, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and JULIA PRESTON
byline.contributor: Matt Apuzzo and Michael S. Schmidt reported from Washington, and Julia Preston from New York. Declan Walsh contributed reporting from Cairo, Salman Masood from Islamabad, Pakistan, and Rick Rojas from San Bernardino, Calif.

lead_paragraph: Tashfeen Malik passed three background checks by American immigration officials but none uncovered what she had said online about her views on violent jihad.

headline.main: U.S. Visa Process Missed San Bernardino Wife’s Online Zealotry
headline.print_headline: Visa Screening Missed an Attacker’s Zealotry on Social Media
